And in that two-and-a-half-day proceeding, Cameron says he presented evidence that Breonna Taylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, did fire the first shot as officers stormed into the apartment, hitting Sergeant Jonathan Mattingly in the leg.
This notion that somehow there was a friendly fire or crossfire that hit Sergeant Mattingly is a silly idea.

Cameron says ballistics tests show the nine millimeter ammo from Walker's gun matches.  the bullet believed to have hit Mattingly.  He disputes recent speculation that Mattingly may have been hit by gunfire from Detective Brett Hankinson, who was outside the building.

To believe that idea is to suggest that somehow bullets that were fired from outside of the apartment down the side of the apartment unit somehow made a sharp turn left to hit Mattingly in order to match up with the entry wound.

And Cameron says because Walker shot first, he did not recommend murder charges against Mattingly and Officer Miles Cosgrove because they were justified in returning fire, even though Taylor was hit in the crossfire.  In your grand jury presentation, did you recommend any charges at all against Either Mattingly or Cosgrove in the shooting of Brenna Taylor.

Well, basically your question is about whether we recommended any murder charges against Cosgrove and Mattingly, and the answer is no.  Ultimately, our judgment is that the charge that we could prove at trial beyond a reasonable doubt was for wanton endangerment, against Mr.  Hankinson.
Cameron says presenting the grand jury with a murder charge would not have been appropriate.

They're an independent body.  If they wanted to make an assessment about different charges, they could have done that.  But our recommendation... was that Mattingly and Cosgrove were justified in their acts and their conduct.
And Cameron says he did tell the jury that the one witness who says he heard the officers announce their presence before knocking down the apartment door later changed his story.
We presented on all of the discrepancies in his testimony.  We provided all of that information to the grand jury for them to hear.  and to process.
Bottom line, in the end, no one faces charges in connection to Taylor's death.
No one, again, doesn't realize the tragedy here, but that also does not give us a license to make charges that are not founded on the law and the facts.
Lawrence, what the protesters have been demanding for months now is justice for Breonna Taylor.  Does Cameron believe that justice has been served in this case?
Well, I asked him that, and Cameron pointed to something he said during his news conference last week, that sometimes criminal law is not adequate to respond to tragedy.

The Attorney General moves to delay release of Breonna Taylor Grand Jury Records.  National Review.  Kentucky Attorney General Daniel Cameron's office on Wednesday announced that it is moving to delay the public release of grand jury records in the case of Breonna Taylor, whose fatal shooting by police in March has ignited protests across the nation.  Cameron's office filed a motion Tuesday night to delay the release of the grand jury records by a week with the aim of protecting the identities of witnesses, especially private citizens, named in the audio recording.  The recording was originally slated to be released publicly later on Wednesday.  The motion requests to redact personal identifiers of any named person, and to redact both names and personal identifiers of any private citizen.  Jefferson Circuit Court Judge Anne Bailey Smith is expected to rule on Cameron's motion on Wednesday.  Taylor, a black 26-year-old emergency medical worker, was shot eight times in her Louisville, Kentucky, apartment on March 13.  Its police officers executed a search warrant for two men who were known to reside there.  The warrant was issued because police suspected that a man connected to a drug ring was receiving packages containing drugs at Taylor's apartment, but no drugs were found in the botched raid.  Last week, the Kentucky Attorney General's Office announced first-degree wanton endangerment charges against one of the officers who shot into Taylor's apartment.  The officer was not charged with murder, and the other two officers involved in the fatal shooting were not charged.  Hours after the charges were announced on Wednesday of last week, protesters took to the streets in Louisville and set fires, caused property damage, and failed to disperse after being warned, police said.  Two Louisville police officers were shot and sustained serious injuries, and nearly 100 protesters were arrested during the night's demonstrations.  Send a tip to the news team at NR.
